title: 113_hr3357
content:
The "Early Childhood Education Professional Improvement Act of 2013" aims to assist States in enhancing the knowledge, credentials, compensation, and professional development of early childhood educators in early childhood education programs. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "early childhood education program" includes Head Start Program, State-funded prekindergarten program, licensed child care for prekindergarten children, and special education preschool. The term "institution of higher education" is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965.

SEC. 4. PROGRAM AUTHORIZED. The Secretary of Education, with input from the Secretary of Health and Human Services, can grant funds to States for implementing activities outlined in section 6. Applications for grants are authorized. Each State seeking a grant under this Act must submit an application to the Secretary of Education, including details of their early childhood professional development system developed in collaboration with the State Advisory Council on Early Childhood Education and Care. The State's system for early childhood professional development was developed in collaboration with various stakeholders, including the State Advisory Council on Early Childhood Education and Care, the State agency responsible for childcare, the State Head Start collaboration director, and other relevant organizations. A State agency is designated to administer the grant program. The State's system for early childhood professional development includes oversight, professional standards, career advancement opportunities, coordination with higher education institutions, and articulation agreements. The curr_chunk discusses coordination with State higher education agencies, accrediting bodies, and two- and four-year institutions, encouraging articulation agreements, and making higher education more accessible for working learners. The curr_chunk focuses on making higher education more accessible for working learners in rural areas, supporting adult learners from low-income or minority communities, using workforce data to assess needs, and financing over time. The curr_chunk focuses on the state's use of funds. The State must use grant funds to provide scholarships for preschool teachers to pursue a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or a related field, and to support teachers with a non-education bachelor's degree to obtain credentials or licensure. To support preschool teachers with non-education bachelor's degrees in obtaining credentials in early childhood education, increase compensation for teachers pursuing early childhood education degrees, and provide ongoing professional development. To support preschool teachers in obtaining early childhood education degrees and increase compensation, while also providing professional development opportunities addressing child development, teacher-child interaction, family engagement, and cultural competence. The curr_chunk focuses on all areas of child development and learning, teacher-child interaction, family engagement, and cultural competence for working with diverse children and families. The Act emphasizes that grant funds should supplement, not replace, existing federal, state, and local funds for early childhood educator preparation. States receiving funds must maintain or increase their fiscal effort for supported activities. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2014 through 2019.
